text:
CURRENT AFFAIRS AND IMPORTANT FACTS (1)

 

Nigeria got her Independence in the year 1960, Then the Queen of England was the Head of State was and was represented by a Governor-General, Dr. Nnamdi Azikiwe, who is the first indigenous Govemor-General in Nigeria. 

 

In 1957 the office of the Prime Minister in Nigeria was created, followed by the election of the first Prime minister in 1960.

 

In 1957 the Eastern and Western regions of Nigeria achieved the status of self-government while the Northern Region achieved the status of self-government in 1959.

 

The central legislature of Nigeria became bicameral in 1960.

 

The head of the first military government in Nigeria was General Johnson Aguiyi-Ironsi

 

The first restructuring in Nigeria was in the year 1963, the Mid-Western Region was formed from the Western Region in 1963 and was effectively governed as fourth region outside the bounds of the Western Region.

 

Southern Nigeria was divided into Eastern and Western Provinces for administrative purposes in 1939.

 

Nigeria adapted the parliamentary cabinet system of government within 1960 and 1966. The members of the cabinet and the ministers were also members of the legislature. All the members of the cabinet were held responsible for any deficiency observed in any one ministry, this a collective responsibility.

 

The Independence Constitution made provision for the post of a Governor-General, which is ceremonial or Titular head of state representing the Queen of England, the overall Head of the country. During this period Dr. Nnamdi Azikiwe was then the Governor-General of the Federal Republic of Nigeria.

 

Sir Fredrick Lugard was the first Governor General of Colonial Nigeria in the year 1914 – 1919.

 

Legislative Council that met in 1923 were noted because they included elected African members.

 

The 3-tier structure was established in the Western Region of Nigeria in the year 1962. These includes: Division, District and Local Councils. Each tier was given responsibilities according to its resources.

 

In 1953 Chief Anthony Enaharo moved the motion that Nigeria should become independent in 1956.

On November 17,1993, General Sanni Abacha, the former military head of state of Nigeria came into power through a palace coup that overthrew the Interim National Government headed by Chief Ernest Shonekan. 

 

On June 8, 1998, General Sanni Abacha died while still in office as head of state. 

 

On November 26, 2011, Chief Odumegwu Emeka Ojukwu, former Biafran Head of State died in London hospital 

 

In 1995, Nigeria was suspended from Commonwealth as a result of human right abuse and bad government 

 

On July 7, 1998 Chief MKO Abiola the winner of June 12, 1993 annulled presidential election in Nigeria died in prison. 

 

In 1999, Julius Nyerere, Tanzania’s founding president died. He introduced a brand of socialism known as Ujama

 

Prince Bola Ajibola was the Chairman of the Nigeria-Cameroon mixed commission on Bakassi peninsular boundary dispute.

 

Martin Luther Agwai, a Nigerian, was the first commander of Joint UN/AU Mission in Darfur (UNSMID) 

 

Africa as centre piece of Nigeria foreign policy was coined under Murtala/Obasanjo military regime, 1975-1979.

 

On May 1968, Ivory Coast President Felix Houphoet Boigny and Tanzania President Julius Nyerere recognized and supported Biafra as an independent state 

 

On may 30, 1967 the Republic of Biafra was declared by General Emeka Odumegwu Ojukwu 

 

On August 10, 1967 General Gowon declared total war against Biafra 

 

On January 9, 1970 General Ojukwu handed over to his second in command major general Philip Effiong and left for Cote d’Ivoire.

 

On January 1st 1973, Nigeria pound was replaced with Naira 

 

On March 1969 Haiti officially recognized Biafra as an independent state 

 

On January 13, 1970, the Nigerian-Biafran war formally ended with the surrender of Biafra. 

 

In 2008, post election power sharing deal between Mwai Kibaki and Raila Odinga of Kenya was mediated by Kofi Annan following post election crises between Orange Democratic Party of Rail Odinga and Party of National Unity of Kibaki. Odinga became the Prime minister and Kibaki the president 

 

In 1986, General Ibrahim Babangida’s government introduced Structural Adjustment Programme in Nigeria as part of the IMF conditionalities. 

 

The first political party formed in Nigeria was NNDP formed by Herbert Macaulay in 1923 The first constitution in Nigeria was the Clifford Constitution of 1922 

 

The 1988 civil service reform in Nigeria was aimed at professionalization of the civil service 

 

The 1975 civil service reform, in Nigeria was aimed at making the civil service more efficient, effective and productive. 

 

The Eleme oil refinery was established in 1965, Warri refinery was 1978, Port Harcourt refinery 1989 and Kaduna refinery 1980.

 

In 1972, Nigerian enterprise promotion Decree known as Indigenization Decree was promoted to increase Nigerians’ share and participation in ownership of key industries in Nigeria. 

 

In 1965, OAU Council of Ministers resolved to break diplomatic relation with Britain for its support to Ian Smith rebellion in Rhodesia. Ian smith unilaterally declared the independence of Rhodesia in 1965 

 

In 1970, Nigeria extended military support to Guinea when the country was faced with threat of mercenary invasion 

 

In 1962, Nigeria abolished Anglo-Nigeria military pact owing to opposition to the pact by Nigerians 

 

Tanzania, Zambia, Angola, Mozambique, Botswana and Zimbabwe are regarded as front line States. Nigeria is also included as a front line state because of the role it played in fight against apartheid policy in South Africa.

 

Apartheid policy was introduced in South African in 1948. It is policy based on racism. 

 

In 1995, Mozambique a Portuguese speaking country joined Commonwealth but was not colonized by Britain. 

 

In 1961, South Africa was suspended from Commonwealth because of its apartheid policy.

 

In 1847, Liberia became the first Independent African state, it was colonized by the USA 

 

Ethiopia was the only African country that was not colonized by European power. The attempt by Italy to colonize Ethiopia was unsuccessful 

 

The search for oil in Nigeria began in 1937 and oil was discovered in Oloibiri in 1956 and production began in 1958 

 

Aba woman riot of 1929 was a demonstration against arbitrary imposition of tax on Nigerians by the colonial master 

 

In 1990, Nelson Mandela was released from prison after 27 years and he visited Nigeria on May 13, 1990 

 

On November 21, 1991 General Olusegun Obasanjo contested for the post of UNO Secretary General but was defeated by Butrous Ghali of Egypt. 

 

Nnamdi Azikwe was the first Premier of Eastern Region. Chief Obafemi Awolowo was the first Premier of Western Region. Ahmadu Bello was the first Premier of Northern Region. Abubakar Tafawa Balewa was the first Prime Minister of Nigeria. 

 

Alhaji Shehu Shagari was the first indigenous Executive president of Nigeria. Nnamdi Azikwe was the first indigenous president of Nigeria. He was a ceremonial president

 

The 1975 Constitutional Drafting Committee in Nigeria was headed by Chief Rotimi Williams 

 

The 1977 Constituent Assembly that reviewed the recommendation of the 1975 Constitutional Drafting Committee report was headed by Justice Udo Udoma 

 

The 1994 constitutional conference in Nigeria was headed by Justice Kariby Whyte 

 

The 2005 constitutional conference in Nigeria was headed by justice Niky Tobi . 

 

On January 20, 2009 Obama Barrack was sworn in as the 44th American President and first African America President 

 

The announcement of the overthrow of government of General Yakubu Gowon was made by Col. Joe Garba 

 

On July 29, the government of General Yakubu Gowon was overthrown when he was attending OAU summit in Kampala, Uganda. 

CURRENT AFFAIRS AND IMPORTANT FACTS (2)

National Party of Nigeria (NPN). NPN was the widest spread of, membership in Nigeria during the Second Republic and it was formed by former leaders of Northern People’s Congress (NPC).

 

The Code of Conduct Bureau is the agency responsible for investigating allegations of mal-administration in the civil service.

 

Nnamdi Azikiwe led the N.C.N.C. to send a delegation to London to protest against the Richards Constitution in the year 1947.

SAP (Structural Adjustment programme) was introduced in Nigeria in the year 1986, during Babangida regime. He introduced it with the main objective of revamping and ailing economy. 

 

 

Lord Frederick Lugard created both the Nigerian council and Legislative Council in 1916, at Lagos. 

Immediately after the Nigeria civil war, Gowon's regime embarked on Reconciliation, rehabilitation and reconstruction.

 

The census crises of 1962/63 was caused by gross irregularities and figure allocation

Africa became the centre-piece (Prime interest) of Nigeria's foreign policy under the regime of Murtala Mohammed. 

 

King William Dappa Pepple was actually removed in the year 1854 by the Britain government. He was regarded as obstacle in the expansion of British trade along the West Coast of Africa.

 

King William D. was actually deposed to Fernando Pole, then to Clarence. He was finally reinstated in 1861, and eventually died in 1866.

 

Fascism are basically opposed to features of democracy. Fascism system was fashioned by an Italian Leader in the early 1920's by name Benito Mussolini.

 

The world organization which existed before the United Nations Organization was the League of Nations.

 

The foreign affairs minister who advocated the "Concert of Medium Powers" was Prof. Bolaji Akinyemi.

 

Nigeria, USA, Brazil, Bolivia, Colombia and Tanzania are examples of Presidential system where the legislature and executive are elected separately to a fixed term. 

 

The formation of ECOWAS was initiated by Nigeria and Togo under the leadership of General Yakubu Gowon and General Gnasingbe Eyadema respectively.

 

NEPAD started in July 2001, at Lusaka, Zambia by the Assembly of Heads of State and Government. It was adopted during the OAU summit.

 

OPEC was established in September, 1960 with the main objective of stabilizing the price in the oil market. The organization is made up of thirteen petroleum exporting countries. In July, 1971 Nigeria as a petroleum exporting country joined OPEC.

 

The first Secretary General of the Commonwealth is Arnold Smith a Canadian who served for 10years (1965 – 1975).

 

UNDP has its headquarters in New York. 

Atomic energy (atomic bomb) tests was carried out in the Sahara Desert by France government in 1961, which made Nigeria to have severe diplomatic relations with France, then Tafawa Balewa was the prime minister. Then in the 1966 the two countries came together diplomatically under General Aguiyi lronsi who was the head of state.

 

Hansard: the official published report of debates in the parliament of a member of the Commonwealth of Nations.

 

On the 1st January, 1990, the Royal Niger Company transferred it’s territory to the British Government.

 

A-4 voting system was introduced into the political process in Nigeria during the Third Republic. It was introduced by Professor Humphrey Nwosu who was the chairman of the National Electoral Commission (NEC).

 

The colonial penetration into Africa was formalized in Berlin conference. They laid a very strong foundation for colonial enterprise and literally divided the continent among European powers, this Nigeria was apportioned to the Great Britain. 

 

The ten non-permanent members of the Security Council are elected by General Assembly.

 

The last European country to abolish slave trade was Portugal. The first European to come to Africa in search of slave was Portugal 

 

The original membership of OAU was 36. Morocco in 1984 withdrew from OAU because of OAU’s (now AU) recognition and admission of Saharawi Arab Democratic Republic as a member. Morroco was readmitted in 2017.

 

Balfour Declaration of 1926 established equal status for British dominions 

 

Former British protectorates that have never joined Commonwealth include Egypt, Iraq, Transjordan, Sudan, Kuwait, Bahrain, Oman, Qatar and United Arab Emirate formed by Egypt and Syria. 

 

The Cold War lasted between 1945 and 1989. 

 

French speaking members of the Commonwealth of Nation include Cameroon, Canada, Dominica, Mauritius, Rwanda, St Lucia, Seychelles and Vanuatu 

 

ECOWAS Bank for Investment and Development was formerly known as Fund for Co-operation. The change in name took place in 2001. 

 

Mauritania withdrew its membership from ECOWAS in 2002. 

 

Former UNO mandated territories that were under Trusteeship Councils of UN0 included: Iraq, Syria, Lebanon, Palestine, Togo, Cameroon, Tanzania, Rwanda, Burundi, Namibia, Pacific Island and Guinea. 

 

The first former African head of state to be convicted on crime against humanity was Charles Taylor of Liberia who was sentenced to 50 years imprisonment by International Criminal Court in Hague in May 2012.

 

The first Nigeria Head of government to die in office was Abubakar Tafawa Balewa, the first Prime Minister, who was assassinated during the first military coup of January 15, 1966 

 

The first Nigeria Head of State to die naturally in office was General Sani Abacha who died on June 8, 1998 

 

The Nigerian Heads of State that died in office are Tafawa Balewa, who was killed on January 15,1966 military coup; General Murtala Mohamr'ned, who was assassinated on January 13, 1976 coup led by Buka Suka Dimka; General Sani Abacha, who died on June 8, 1998 and President Shehu Musa Yar’Adua who died in may 2010. 

 

The highest policy making organ under General Yakubu Gowon military regime in Nigeria was Supreme Military Council (SMC) 

 

The highest policy making organ under General Ibrahim Babangida’s military regime in Nigeria was Armed Forces Ruling Council (AFRC) 

 

The highest policy making organ under General Sanni Abacha’s military regime in Nigeria was Provisional Ruling Council (PRC).

 

The chairman of the committee that recommended the transfer of Federal Capital Territory to Abuja was Justice Akinola Aguda.

The chairman of INEC that introduced the use of card reader machines and permanent voters card in Nigeria electoral process was Professor Atahiru Jega. Jega introduced this measure during the 2015 general election to check electoral malpractices and ensure credible election. 

 

APC became the first opposition party to win presidential election in the history of Nigeria. President Goodluck accepted his defeat and refused to challenge the presidential result in court and therefore became the first defeated incumbent president in Nigeria that did not challenge the result. 

 

The two parties which formed the coalition government in Nigeria in 1959 after the general election were NPC and NCNC.

 

Southem Nigeria was divided into Eastern and Western provience in 1939 by governor Bernard Bourdlion.

 

Before the formation of OAU Nigeria belong to regional group /block known as the Monrovia group.

 

The constitution which introduced ministerial system in Nigeria was Marcpherson constitutiori of 1951 

 

Under military regime there is fusion of executive and legislative power. It is the judicial organ that is separate to an extent 

 

The Obasanjo Administration nationalized the assets of the British petroleum because of British government policy in South Africa and Zimbabwe. The Obasanjo led military administration nationalized the British Petroleum and Bardays Bank in Nigeria in reaction to British continued trade link with South Africa. 

 

The British petroleum was nationalized because of British reluctance to grant independence to Zimbabwe while Barclay bank (union bank) was because of British business/trade link with aparthaid South Africa.

 

Under the 1976 local government reform traditional rulers were granted ceremonial or advisory function. 

 

It was the 1979 constitution of Nigeria that first recognized local government as the third tier of government but it was in 1976 local government reform that local government was made the third tier. Under 1976 reform, functions of local government was carried out by local government council. Local government is an example of devolution of power. 

 

The precolonial administrative systems/societies of the Igbo, Tiv and Ibibio were decentralized while that of Hausa-Fulani, Yoruba and Benin was centralized.

 

The Hausa-Fulam‘ society had absolute monarch while that of Benin and Yoruba was constitutional monarch. The Benin system was primogenitural because ruling status or kingsz was transferred from father to son. 

 

The body that made law in Nigeria in the First Republic (1963-1966) was called parliament but in the Second Republic (1979-1983) the name was change to National Assembly. The law made by the parliament is an Act of parliament while the law made by the National Assembly is an Act of the National Assembly. 

 

The major liberation organizations that fought for the independence of Zimbabwe was ZANU; for Namibia it was SWAPO; for South Africa it was ANC; for Mozambique it was FRILIMO.

 

The 1960 constitution of Nigeria was mornachical and parliamentary in nature because the British monarch was the head of state represented by a governor-general. 

 

The term federal character was popularised by Murtala/ Obasanjo regime to ensure equity in distribution of public offices as well as non dominance of an ethnic group in public offices. 

 

Political power entails naked force when it is exercised without governmental legitimacy 

 

The comprador bourgeosie are Nigerian business men or capitalists that represent foreign interest while national bourgeoisie are those that represent Nigeria interest 

 

 

The order in which the European groups penetrated into the interior of Nigeria was explorers, traders, missionaries and imperialists.

 

Nigeria is the major share holder in African Development Bank (ADB) 

 

A tax law is an example of public bill because it affects the public 

 

The first Nigeria law making body after amalgamation was known as the Nigeria Council of 1914. However, this body did not have real legislative power but advisory role. The body was created by Lord Lugard.

 

Under Babangida regime the Political Bureau recommended unicameral legislature and multiparty system 

 

EXTRA CURRENT AFFAIRS

Adisa Akinloye was the first National Chairman of National Party of Nigeria (NPN) 

 

Chief Solomon Lar was the first National Chairman of Peoples Democratic Party (PDP) 

 

The first Nigerian Lawyer to serve as a judge of International Court of Justice at Hague was Charles Onyeama (1966).

 

The first Nigerian to be president of International Court of Justice was T. O. Elias (1972) 

 

The first Nigerian president of the Senate was Nnamdi Azikiwe. Nnamdi Azikwe was the first Premier of Eastern Region 

 

The first Nigerian chief representative in UNO was Matthew Tawo Mbu (appointed 1959) but Simeon Adebo was the first permanent representative (appointed 1962) 

 

The first Nigerian secretary of Economic Commission for Africa (ECA) was Adedeji Adebayo.

The first Nigerian secretary of OPEC was Yahaya Dikko (1982) 

 

The first Nigerian president of UNO was Joseph Garba (1989) 

 

The first military Head of State in Nigeria was General Aguiyi Ironsi.

 

Farouk Abdulmutallab, a Nigerian and a 23year old Islamic fundamentalist, linked with al Qaeda, on 25th December 2009 attempted to bomb a US plane carrying 289 people with an explosive hidden under his pants. Mutallab admitted before a US court that he was out to avenge America’s killing of his Muslim brothers across the globe and was sentences to life imprisonment in February 2012. 

 

In 1995, Nigeria activist Ken Saro Wiwa and eight other Ogoni activists were executed by the government of General Sani Abacha 

 

 

On August 6, 2008, General Moktar Ould Daddah of Mauritania overthrew President Maaouiya Ould Taya. 

 

In 1991, Ethiopian president Mengistu Haile Mariam and Somali’s president Mohamed Siad Barre were ousted from power. 

 

In 1991, Civil War started in Sierra Leone. In 1992, Frederick Chiluba replaced Kenneth Kaunda as the president of Zambia 

 

The first African woman to be elected president of UNO General Assembly was Angie Brook of Liberia 

 

The first civilian governor to be impeached in Nigeria was Balarabe Musa of Kaduna State in 1981.

 

Ghana gained her independence in the year 1957

 

Guinea gained her independence in the year 1958

 

Nigeria gained her independence in the year 1960

 

In 1974, Guinea-Bissau became independence from Portugal its colonial master. 

 

On July 9, 2011, Southern Sudan became an independent state from Sudan. 

 

In 1993, Eritrea became an independent state from Ethiopia. 

 

Countries like Liberia and Ethiopia were never colonized. 

According to Karl Marx. the mode of production it moves from Feudalism, Capitalism, Socialism, Communism. 

 

Fascism originated from Italy. 

 

The Igbos were massacred in the North between September and October, 1966

In 1990, Namibia became an independent country. 

 

In 1988, UNO imposed sanction on Libya over the bombing of a Panam Flight in Scotland 

 

On October 20, 2011 Muamar Ghaddafi, the president of Libya was killed by combine forces of NATO and revolutionary group that ousted him from power after ruling for 42 years. 

 

On May 2, 2011, Osama Bin Laden the al-Qaeda leader was killed by USA forces in Pakistan. 

 

 

In 1994, South Africa held its first democratic election and Nelson Mandela was elected president: the first black African president of South Africa. 

 

In 1997 Charles Taylor was elected the president of Liberia and in 2007 he was handed over to International Criminal Court in Hague on charges of War Crime during Sierra Leone Civil War and in 2012 he was sentenced to 50 years imprisonment by International Criminal Court in Hague. 

 

In 1997, Laurent-Desire Kabila became the president of Democratic Republic of Congo after forcing President Mobutu Seseseko into exile 

 

In July 1962, Belgium granted full independence to Rwanda and Burundi 

 

In 1994, Rwanda genocide began When the Hutus extremists took over the government and massacred the Tutsi

 

In 2008, International Criminal Court ordered the arrest of Sudan president Omar al-Bashir for his crime against humanity in Sudan.

 

The USA Congress is made up of 100 Senators, two from each of the fifty states that make up the USA.
